tool.name: snippy-core
tool.description: Combine multiple Snippy outputs into a core SNP alignment
tool.command: #for $indir in $indirs #set $sample_name = os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(str($indir.name)))[0] mkdir '$sample_name' && tar -xf '$indir' -C '$sample_name' --strip-components=1 && #end for ls -lh . && #set snippy_dirs = ' '.join([os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(str($indir.name)))[0] for $indir in $indirs]) snippy-core --ref '$ref' ${snippy_dirs}

param.name: indirs
param.label: Snippy input zipped dirs
param.help: Select all the snippy inputs for alignment

param.name: ref
param.label: Reference File (either in fasta or genbank format)
param.help: Fasta or Genbank file to use as the reference

param.name: outputs
param.label: Output selection
param.option: A core SNP alignment in the fasta format
A whole genome SNP alignment (includes invariant sites)
Tab-separated columnar list of core SNP sites with alleles and annotations
Tab-separated columnar list of alignment/core-size statistics

tool.help:
**snippy-core @VERSION@**
Combine multiple Snippy outputs into a core SNP alignment
If you call SNPs for multiple isolates from the same reference, you can produce an alignment of "core SNPs" which can be used to build a high-resolution phylogeny (ignoring possible recombination). A "core site" is a genomic position that is present in all the samples. A core site can have the same nucleotide in every sample ("monomorphic") or some samples can be different ("polymorphic" or "variant"). If we ignore the complications of "ins", "del" variant types, and just use variant sites, these are the "core SNP genome".
**Inputs:**
Multiple Snippy output directories. (At least 2 of)
**Options:**
- noreference Exclude reference (default '0').
**Note:**
snippy **must** have been run with --cleanup False
